item.title: Covid: UK marks one year since the first lockdown
item.description: A minute's silence will be held at midday as part of a national day of reflection for 126,000 deaths.

item.title: Covid: £5,000 fine for people going on holiday abroad
item.description: It is due to come into force in England next week as some other lockdown restrictions are eased.

item.title: Salmond committee criticises 'serious flaws' of Scottish government
item.description: A committee of MSPs says the female complainers were badly let down by the Scottish government.

item.title: Jobless crisis shows signs of easing but under-25s hit hard
item.description: The number of workers on UK company payrolls climbed by 200,000 in the three months to February.

item.title: Coronavirus: Germany imposes Easter lockdown to curb new surge
item.description: Rising infections have put Germany in a "very serious" situation, Chancellor Angela Merkel says.

item.title: Colorado shootings: 'We heard boom, boom, boom'
item.description: A gunman has killed 10 people, including a police officer, in the US state of Colorado.

item.title: Abortion: Brandon Lewis to take powers over Stormont laws
item.description: MPs from across Parliament have written to Stormont ministers in support of the significant move.

item.title: Shrewsbury 24: Court of Appeal clears picketers' convictions
item.description: The 14 men, including actor Ricky Tomlinson, were among 24 charged following pickets in Shrewsbury.

item.title: Bobby Brown Jr died of accidental overdose, says coroner
item.description: The son of singer Bobby Brown was found dead in his home last November.

item.title: Machine finds tantalising hints of new physics
item.description: A team working at the Large Hadron Collider finds signs of new physical laws.

item.title: Frank Worthington: Former England striker dies aged 72 following long illness
item.description: Former England striker Frank Worthington dies aged 72 following a long illness.

item.title: The Papers: 'Travel ban extended' and 'a day to reflect' on lockdown
item.description: Britons facing tighter travel restrictions makes the front of some newspapers on the anniversary of the start of lockdown.

item.title: Covid-19: One year of lockdowns across the UK
item.description: It's a year to the day since the first UK-wide coronavirus lockdown was announced.

item.title: Lockdown newborns: 'A crazy year to bring a baby into the world'
item.description: Four mums share their experiences of having a baby amid coronavirus lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Former Scotland player opens up about over-exercising
item.description: Tom Philip has spoken about his experience with over-exercising and strict dieting to hide his poor mental health.

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccines and vaccine passports being sold on darknet
item.description: Researchers say criminals are taking advantage of desperate people looking for a way out of lockdown

item.title: Afghanistan: The women killed for working at a TV station.
item.description: A television station in Afghanistan has sent all of its female employees home after four were killed by extremists.

item.title: Waitrose ditches magazines with disposable plastic toys
item.description: The retailer will not sell magazines with disposable plastic toys after a campaign by a 10-year-old.

item.title: Jack Dorsey's first ever tweet sells for $2.9m
item.description: The Twitter founder will donate the money to charity after it was bought by a Malaysia-based businessman.

item.title: Covid: Penguins' move from Isle of Man to Northern Ireland 'a miracle'
item.description: Covid rules force keepers to move 14 birds across four countries to get to their new home.

item.title: Huge fire sweeps through Rohingya camp in Bangladesh
item.description: A massive blaze engulfed the camp in Cox's Bazar, killing several people and destroying homes.

item.title: How Iceland clamped down to conquer coronavirus
item.description: It may be a remote island, but there is a reason why Iceland is proud of its success in tackling the pandemic.

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has warned it could ban exports of vaccines made in the bloc. How would this affect the UK?

item.title: Covid: The Clacton GP who took his staff on holiday with him
item.description: How the death of a GP led to an "outpouring of love" in the town where he worked.

item.title: Grenfell Tower inquiry: 9 things we now know about the cladding
item.description: A public inquiry has questioned employees of the metals firm that supplied cladding for Grenfell.

item.title: What is happening to the size of the Army?
item.description: Defence spending is going up, but the number of soldiers in the Army is going to fall.

item.title: Erin Brockovich: California water battle 'woke me up'
item.description: She has continued to call for safe water in the decades since the major case in the town of Hinkley.

item.title: Making honey without bees and milk without cows
item.description: Firms are using fermentation to produce honey and milk and say they can match the taste of the real thing.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Dan Gertler: The man at the centre of DR Congo corruption allegations
item.description: Dan Gertler formed a close relationship with DR Congo's ex-leader, even getting a diplomatic passport.

item.title: Schumacher ready to emulate 'idol' father - but it won't be easy
item.description: Mick Schumacher starts his Formula 1 career this weekend in Bahrain as a rookie like no other.

item.title: 'Grealish should be number one' - who you & pundits say should start for England
item.description: England boss Gareth Southgate is spoilt for choice in attack this summer - this is who you and our pundits think should play with Harry Kane.

item.title: Chris Froome dropped during first Volta a Catalunya stage
item.description: Chris Froome finishes more than eight minutes behind the peloton on the first stage of the Volta a Catalunya.

item.title: Stretford Paddock: The Man Utd fan TV team with lofty ambitions
item.description: Stretford Paddock began life as a fan TV channel but have now set up a football club and have dreams of making swift progress.

item.title: MOTDx: Grenfell Athletic - the football club trying to heal a community
item.description: MOTDx visits west London to speak to the members of Grenfell Athletic, a football team founded in the wake of the devastating Grenfell Tower fire in 2017 with the aim of healing the community.

item.title: Mick Schumacher: 'I'm happy to have brought the name back into F1'
item.description: Haas driver Mick Schumacher says having such a famous name brings him "motivation and pride" as he prepares for his F1 debut.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid lockdown: Seven enduring claims fact-checked
item.description: A year after the first UK lockdown began, there are many who doubt the necessity of such restrictions.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The culture secretary has said they are looking at "covid certification" for attending large events

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 28 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
item.description: Jang Yeong-jin fled North Korea to escape a loveless marriage. Now he is engaged to his boyfriend.
